channel.title: ArchLinux: Because we're only 40% Obsolete
channel.description:
Another interesting thing I found posted on the Arch forums.
According to [url=http://oswatershed.org/]THIS[/url] article archlinux is the most up-to-date distro (according to the distros he compared)
Which would be
Arch, Fedora, Ubuntu, Gentoo, Funtoo, Sabayon, Slackware, Debian, and Opensuse.
Obviously 40% of the packages Arch maintains aren't out-of-date he monitored a select group of packages for each distro (to make it fair I suppose) which included
[code] alsa-utils, cups, emacs, firefox, gcc, ghostscript-gpl, gimp, glibc, gnome-desktop, gnupg, httpd (apache), kdebase, linux, NetworkManager, openssh, pidgin, postgresql, python, ruby, xorg-server [/code]
Discuss!

item.title: ArchLinux: Because we're only 40% Obsolete
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

Also its not like the packages that make their way into core/extra aren’t tested first, if its a major change ie xorg 1.6 or a diff nvidia driver version new kernel etc, it goes through ‘testing’ repo first and patches are submitted if needed.

Read full topic

item.title: ArchLinux: Because we're only 40% Obsolete
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:290040”]Cutting-edge isn’t always a good thing, open source is all about release early, release often. That means that every release isn’t stable, in fact most early releases aren’t stable. I would bet that a linux distro that freshly compiled all programs in it’s distro as soon as they were released would not even be remotely usable, because the bugs in early releases would cause it to crash all the time.

There is a fine line to walk between cutting-edge and stable, obviously when you install debian stable you aren’t looking for a system that will be cutting-edge, but instead you want one that will be perfectly stable, and since they spent 2 years working up to the release with thousands testing it and are only doing bug and security fixes without trying anything new chances are it will be stable. Distros like Arch have their place too, but since it is a ‘rolling release’ and they release packages when and as they feel, things have a tendency to break more and you don’t want your network or ssh breaking down when you are running a server.[/quote]
Of course, the above post is correct. You’d never want to use a ‘rolling release’ distribution for a server/mission-critical operations. However, Arch’s behavior is perfectly fine for a workstation.

Read full topic

item.title: ArchLinux: Because we're only 40% Obsolete
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

and yet, as a bleeding edge distro, still no ssl vuln

i dont use it on servers though

Read full topic

item.title: ArchLinux: Because we're only 40% Obsolete
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Cutting-edge isn’t always a good thing, open source is all about release early, release often. That means that every release isn’t stable, in fact most early releases aren’t stable. I would bet that a linux distro that freshly compiled all programs in it’s distro as soon as they were released would not even be remotely usable, because the bugs in early releases would cause it to crash all the time.

There is a fine line to walk between cutting-edge and stable, obviously when you install debian stable you aren’t looking for a system that will be cutting-edge, but instead you want one that will be perfectly stable, and since they spent 2 years working up to the release with thousands testing it and are only doing bug and security fixes without trying anything new chances are it will be stable. Distros like Arch have their place too, but since it is a ‘rolling release’ and they release packages when and as they feel, things have a tendency to break more and you don’t want your network or ssh breaking down when you are running a server.

Read full topic

item.title: ArchLinux: Because we're only 40% Obsolete
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

I don’t see how he can predict the obsoleteness of a distro that hasn’t been released yet.

Read full topic
